title: 107_s1676
content: The "Affordable Small Business Stimulus Act of 2001" amends the 1986 Code to increase expense treatment for small businesses. The "Affordable Small Business Stimulus Act of 2001" increases the dollar limitation for aggregate costs under Section 179(b)(1) to $35,000 ($25,000 for taxable years starting in 2001), with an inflation adjustment for years after 2002. The "Affordable Small Business Stimulus Act of 2001" raises the limit for Section 179(b)(1) costs to $35,000 ($25,000 for 2001), with adjustments for inflation. Section 179(b)(2) is amended to reduce the limitation for deductible section 179 property costs exceeding $350,000 ($250,000 in 2001). The limit for deductible section 179 property costs exceeding $350,000 ($250,000 in 2001) is subject to inflation adjustments for taxable years after 2002. The limit for deductible section 179 property costs exceeding $350,000 ($250,000 in 2001) is subject to inflation adjustments for taxable years after 2002. Any amount not a multiple of $10,000 will be rounded to the nearest multiple of $10,000. The time of deduction for certain depreciable business assets is amended to include the option of electing the preceding taxable year if the property was purchased in that year. These amendments will apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2000. SEC. 3. MODIFICATIONS OF EXCLUSIONS AND ROLLOVERS OF GAIN ON QUALIFIED SMALL BUSINESS STOCK. The exclusion for gain on qualified small business stock is increased from 50 percent to 75 percent. Additionally, a 100-percent exclusion is introduced for critical technology and specialized small business investment businesses. The exclusion for gain on qualified small business stock is increased to 75 percent, and a 100 percent exclusion is introduced for critical technology corporations and specialized small business investment companies. The exclusion for gain on qualified small business stock is increased to 75 percent, and a 100 percent exclusion is introduced for critical technology corporations and specialized small business investment companies. Amendments include increasing empowerment zone benefits to 100 percent and reducing the holding period from 5 years to 3 years. The exclusion for gain on qualified small business stock is amended to reduce the holding period from 5 years to 3 years. Additionally, stock held among members of a controlled group is not eligible for the exclusion, and larger businesses are now eligible for the exclusion. The exclusion for gain on qualified small business stock is amended to reduce the holding period from 5 years to 3 years. Larger businesses are now eligible for the exclusion with an increased asset limitation of $100,000,000, adjusted for inflation annually. The exclusion for gain on qualified small business stock is amended to reduce the holding period from 5 years to 3 years. Additionally, the period to purchase replacement stock and qualify for rollover is increased from 60 days to 180 days. The amendments apply to stock issued after the date of the enactment of this Act. The exclusion for gain on qualified small business stock is amended to reduce the holding period from 5 years to 3 years and the period to purchase replacement stock for rollover is increased from 60 days to 180 days. These amendments apply to stock issued after the date of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 4. RECOVERY PERIOD FOR DEPRECIATION OF COMPUTERS AND PERIPHERAL EQUIPMENT AND COMPUTER SOFTWARE. The recovery period for computers and peripheral equipment is amended to a 3-year period under section 168(e)(3). This includes computers and peripheral equipment as defined in subsection (i)(2)(B). The recovery period for qualified technological equipment is amended to 5 years, while computers or peripheral equipment have a 3-year recovery period for depreciation. The recovery period for qualified technological equipment is amended to 5 years, while computers or peripheral equipment have a 3-year recovery period for depreciation. Additionally, the useful life for depreciation of computer software is reduced from 36 months to 24 months. These changes apply to property placed in service after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 5. DEDUCTION FOR 100 PERCENT OF HEALTH INSURANCE COSTS OF SELF-EMPLOYED INDIVIDUALS. SEC. 5 amends section 162(l) to allow a 100 percent deduction for insurance covering medical care for the taxpayer, spouse, and dependents. It clarifies that this deduction does not apply if the taxpayer participates in a subsidized health plan from an employer other than one described in section 401(c)(4). The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2000. SEC. 6. Disclosure of taxpayer identity information and signatures to State agencies for combined employment tax reporting purposes. Section 6103(d)(5) is amended to allow the Secretary to disclose information for approved combined Federal and State employment tax reporting programs. Certain restrictions on disclosures do not apply in this case. SEC. 7. Farmers and fishermen income averaging does not increase alternative minimum tax liability. Section 55(c) is amended to exclude income averaging for farmers and fishermen in computing regular tax. Section 1301 is amended to allow income averaging for fishermen in addition to farmers. Amendment to section 1301 allows income averaging for fishermen, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2001. Fishing business is defined as commercial fishing under the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act. SEC. 8. Modification of unrelated business income limitation on investment in certain debt-financed properties. Section 514(c)(6) is amended to include indebtedness incurred by a small business investment company licensed under the Small Business Investment Act of 1958. This applies to acquisitions made on or after the enactment of this Act.
